file_metadata.authors: ["Thomas F. Varley", "Vaibhav P. Pai", "Caitlin Grasso", "Jeantine Lunshof", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard"]
file_metadata.title: Identification of brain-like functional information architectures in embryonic tissue of Xenopus laevis

chunks.text: Understanding how cells coordinate activity to produce complex structures and behaviors is a fundamental biological issue. This study uses complex systems science and information theory to infer collective organization in non-neural tissue, applying techniques developed in neuroscience to analyze calcium recordings from basal Xenobots and fMRI recordings from human brains. These techniques, including functional connectivity network structure, modularity, and higher-order information, have been used in neuroscience to study cognitive, clinical, and behavioral states.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigates collective cell coordination in non-neural tissue using techniques from complex systems science and information theory, comparing basal Xenobots and human brains.
chunks.authors: ["Thomas F. Varley", "Vaibhav P. Pai", "Caitlin Grasso", "Jeantine Lunshof", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Basal Xenobots exhibit a "brain-like" functional information architecture, including positive and negative functional connections, meso-scale communities, higher-order interactions (redundant and synergistic), and integrated information. Comparison with personalized null models, preserving first-order statistics while disrupting higher-order interactions, confirms these are genuine higher-order interactions. These similarities suggest that such patterns either arose independently, are epiphenomenal byproducts of conserved dynamics, or directly support adaptive behavior across diverse living systems.
chunks.chunk_summary: Basal Xenobots demonstrate a complex functional information architecture similar to brains, suggesting shared principles of information processing.
chunks.authors: ["Thomas F. Varley", "Vaibhav P. Pai", "Caitlin Grasso", "Jeantine Lunshof", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Biological systems exhibit organized complexity and dynamic problem-solving capacity, coordinating cells and tissues for self-assembly and repair. Quantifying this high-level organization is challenging due to the multi-scale nature of biological processes. Parallels exist between electrophysiological networks in the brain and non-brain tissue, but knowledge gaps remain regarding information patterns in these tissues. This study addresses this by investigating information distribution and dependencies in basal Xenobots and human brains.
chunks.chunk_summary: Biological systems exhibit organized complexity and dynamic problem-solving, but quantifying this organization is challenging, motivating this study's comparison of information dynamics in basal Xenobots and human brains.
chunks.authors: ["Thomas F. Varley", "Vaibhav P. Pai", "Caitlin Grasso", "Jeantine Lunshof", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Computational neuroscience tools, developed for analyzing fMRI, EEG, and MEG data, reveal complex interactions in the brain. This study extends these techniques to basal Xenobots, comparing them to human fMRI data to determine if observed brain patterns are brain-specific or reflect broader biological information processing principles. This contributes to Diverse Intelligence research, which explores cognitive capacities across various substrates.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study applies computational neuroscience tools to compare information processing in basal Xenobots and human brains, contributing to Diverse Intelligence research.
chunks.authors: ["Thomas F. Varley", "Vaibhav P. Pai", "Caitlin Grasso", "Jeantine Lunshof", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Basal Xenobots, self-assembling constructs from Xenopus laevis ectoderm cells, are used in biorobotics. Their lack of a nervous system, synthetic nature, and amenability to optical interrogation make them an interesting model for comparison with neural constructs. Both basal Xenobots and brains can be subdivided into parts (cells or cortical parcels), allowing for analysis of interactions between these parts and the whole system using time series data.
chunks.topic: Basal Xenobots as a model system
chunks.chunk_summary: Basal Xenobots, lacking a nervous system and amenable to optical interrogation, serve as a valuable model for comparing information dynamics with neural constructs like the human brain.
chunks.authors: ["Thomas F. Varley", "Vaibhav P. Pai", "Caitlin Grasso", "Jeantine Lunshof", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: This study compares information dynamics in basal Xenobots and human brains, focusing on higher-order interactions. Both systems exhibit greater integration than expected if elements were independent. A circular-shift null model preserves first-order features while disrupting higher-order interactions, allowing for accurate assessment of higher-order integration. The study hypothesizes that basal Xenobots will show non-trivial information structure despite their relative simplicity compared to the brain.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study compares higher-order interactions in basal Xenobots and human brains using a circular-shift null model to control for lower-order dynamics.
chunks.authors: ["Thomas F. Varley", "Vaibhav P. Pai", "Caitlin Grasso", "Jeantine Lunshof", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Basal Xenobots exhibit non-trivial information structure, with higher-order integration significantly greater than expected in null data. Both basal Xenobots and brains show widespread positive and negative functional correlations, forming functional connectivity networks. These networks exhibit a negative correlation between functional edge weight and Euclidean distance, similar to brains, indicating spatially-embedded functional organization.
chunks.chunk_summary: Basal Xenobots demonstrate non-trivial functional connectivity networks with spatially-embedded organization, similar to human brains.
chunks.authors: ["Thomas F. Varley", "Vaibhav P. Pai", "Caitlin Grasso", "Jeantine Lunshof", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Both brains and basal Xenobots exhibit meso-scale community structures in their functional connectivity networks, with positive correlations within communities and anticorrelations between them. In basal Xenobots, cells within modules tend to be closer in space, a pattern also observed in fMRI scans. These modules may reflect distinct cell types or future differentiated systems in basal Xenobots.
chunks.chunk_summary: Both brains and basal Xenobots exhibit meso-scale community structures in their functional connectivity networks, with spatial proximity within modules.
chunks.authors: ["Thomas F. Varley", "Vaibhav P. Pai", "Caitlin Grasso", "Jeantine Lunshof", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Time-resolved analysis reveals dynamic integration and segregation balance in both systems. Both exhibit significantly higher variance in the root-sum-squares (RSS) of co-fluctuations compared to nulls, indicating a mixture of transient integration and segregation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Time-resolved analysis shows dynamic integration and segregation balance in both brains and basal Xenobots, with higher variance in co-fluctuation RSS compared to nulls.
chunks.authors: ["Thomas F. Varley", "Vaibhav P. Pai", "Caitlin Grasso", "Jeantine Lunshof", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Basal Xenobots and brains show enriched higher-order information dependencies compared to nulls. Both exhibit significantly higher total correlation, dual total correlation, and absolute O-information, indicating complex multivariate interactions. Both systems also show significantly more redundancy and synergy, suggesting sophisticated information processing similar to human brains.
chunks.chunk_summary: Both basal Xenobots and brains demonstrate enriched higher-order information dependencies, including total correlation, dual total correlation, O-information, redundancy, and synergy.
chunks.authors: ["Thomas F. Varley", "Vaibhav P. Pai", "Caitlin Grasso", "Jeantine Lunshof", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Both systems exhibit higher TSE complexity compared to nulls, indicating a non-trivial balance between integration and segregation. This suggests sophisticated multi-cell coordination in basal Xenobots, similar to human brain activity.
chunks.chunk_summary: Higher TSE complexity in both systems suggests a non-trivial balance between integration and segregation, indicating sophisticated multi-cell coordination.
chunks.authors: ["Thomas F. Varley", "Vaibhav P. Pai", "Caitlin Grasso", "Jeantine Lunshof", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Both basal Xenobots and brains demonstrate significantly greater dynamic integrated information compared to nulls, indicating higher predictive power when modeling the system based on its true joint statistics. This suggests that both systems integrate information over time.
chunks.chunk_summary: Both systems show greater dynamic integrated information, indicating temporal information integration.
chunks.authors: ["Thomas F. Varley", "Vaibhav P. Pai", "Caitlin Grasso", "Jeantine Lunshof", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: The consistent finding of greater structure in both brains and basal Xenobots compared to null models suggests shared features of structural organization despite their different biological substrates. This raises questions about the generality of these organizational principles across diverse living systems.
chunks.chunk_summary: The consistent finding of greater structure in both systems suggests shared organizational principles across diverse living systems.
chunks.authors: ["Thomas F. Varley", "Vaibhav P. Pai", "Caitlin Grasso", "Jeantine Lunshof", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard"]
